comment.author: 12512219@N06
comment._content: La caballería era el arma más temible del ejército mexicano.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
A estas tropas por el color de sus camisas y quepíes se les llamaba "amarillos", eran fieles al ejército federal de Don Porfirio.
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: The stream of men from left to right flows from south to north, El Paso is behint the bull ring.  The pipes and smoke plume should be El Paso smelter.

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content:
Found in El Paso Herald issue February 22, 1911 (The Library of Congress, Chronicling America) an article that mentions the soldiers where moved from Juárez bullring to another
quarter behind the customs house.
Is it possible the Call Nr. locates this picture on February 1911?
Dr. Roberto Duarte

comment.author: 34904489@N07
comment._content:
Dr. Duarte:

While it is quite possible this photograph does date from February 1911, we cannot be positive, as the Bain News Service did not always number their negatives chronologically.  Often that is the case in the collection, but not all the time.  This is a very interesting piece of information you have found, though, and may be an explanation for the activity shown.  We can add more details than are currently present in the record.  Thank you!

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Then picture LC-B2-2196-16, "MEXICAN SOLDIERS", should be part of a series (phogographic assay) and the soldiers seem marching across the street to the bullring.

comment.author: 9688250@N02
comment._content: If that's the old ASARCO smelter in the distant background, that's West. So, this would be on today's Abraham Gonzalez (East-West) near Av. Francisco Villa (North-South), presuming that the bullring has never moved from it's current location. I think I see the train tracks on Av. Villa behind the wagon?

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Hi there in The Library of Congress and everybody you all are invited to visit my gallery in www.flickr.com/photos/jesusduarte/ where you may find today's matching picture www.flickr.com/photos/jesusduarte/5868139426/in/photostream

comment.author: 53461717@N08
comment._content: Carta Blanca and Bohemia  were (and still are) beers brewed by Cervecería Cuauhtemoc in Monterrey, Nuevo León, México.  The ads reffer to the beers were selled during the bullfight.
